pr_title: feat(iot-service): Add proxy support for service client operations

timeline.bodyText: Note that this would be a breaking change, but this getter/setter hasn't been in a released jar file yet, so it is still safe to change
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText:
I am not sure what this means:
Only HTTP Proxies are supported. Authentication with the HTTP proxy is not supported.
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: It means you can use HTTP proxies, but only if that HTTP proxy doesn't require authentication. I can reword this
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: text needs to be: Could not get port hostname from saved proxy
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: Is this.proxyOptions.getProxy() check required? There is only 1 public constructor for initializing the ProxyOptions class, and that takes in a Proxy object.
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Good point, just checking if proxyoptions is null should be sufficient here and everywhere else
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: What is the preferable way to set transport configurations for this SDK? Do we take in any transport settings? How do we set the keep-alive time etc?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -38,6 +40,19 @@
      * @throws IOException This exception is thrown if the object creation failed
      */
     public static ServiceClient createFromConnectionString(String connectionString, IotHubServiceClientProtocol iotHubServiceClientProtocol) throws IOException
+    {
+        return createFromConnectionString(connectionString, iotHubServiceClientProtocol, null);
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Create ServiceClient from the specified connection string
+     * @param iotHubServiceClientProtocol  protocol to use
+     * @param connectionString The connection string for the IotHub

+     * @return The created ServiceClient object
+     * @throws IOException This exception is thrown if the object creation failed
+     */
+    public static ServiceClient createFromConnectionString(String connectionString, IotHubServiceClientProtocol iotHubServiceClientProtocol, ProxyOptions proxyOptions) throws IOException

replies.bodyText: We currently don't have any other options beyond proxy settings. I don't see us extending other options like the C# SDK does right now. I see that as something we can address when this SDK goes track 2 instead.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: No one has asked for any settings beyond proxy support, for reference
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I see, it's better to start off with a config file, rather than placing them in the client initializer; but I agree, now that we are this close to going track 2, we should do it there directly.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Well now I am building RegistryManagerOptions and ServiceClientOptions classes as per Priyanka, in case you are still interested in this point
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: are 8 spaces of indentation normal for Java?
timeline.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText: Not quite, I can fix this
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: What is normal?
replies.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText:
One tab over from the method that started the fluent chain:
Although github won't let me demonstrate exactly how this looks, the latest view of this file should show you.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: InetSocketAddress uses a capital N in getHostName. Not sure if that is the preferred casing to stick with and match for this method.
timeline.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText: Ah, good catch. We do use HostName and Hostname very interchangeably in this SDK. HostName seems more appropriate considering it is a pair of words
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Perhaps message should be "Unsupported proxy type" then
timeline.author: drwill-ms

timeline.bodyText: space before : ?
timeline.author: drwill-ms

timeline.bodyText: More of a question than PR comments: Does java support only setting proxies explicitly via the application, or does it also automatically tunnel traffic through a proxy set on the OS directly?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+package com.microsoft.azure.sdk.iot.service;
+
+import lombok.Getter;
+
+import java.net.InetSocketAddress;
+import java.net.Proxy;
+
+/**
+ * The settings supported by this SDK when communicating to IoT Hub through a proxy. HTTP proxies are supported by this SDK,
+ * but only if the proxy does not require authentication.
+ */
+public class ProxyOptions
+{
+    @Getter
+    private Proxy proxy;
+
+    /**
+     * Create the proxy options for connecting to a proxy
+     * @param proxy the proxy to communicate through
+     */
+    public ProxyOptions(Proxy proxy)

replies.bodyText: What I mean is, if I have both set, who wins?
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Java doesn't allow you to force a proxy like that at the OS level as far as I know. Since we use transport libraries for HTTP and AMQP, we have to set the proxy at the http/amqp client level
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: So if I understand correctly, if my OS would have some default proxy configured, that would never be honored?
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Yes, hence why customer's want proxy support on this SDK, instead of just setting it on their own devices
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Interesting!
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: What are the hurdles with AMQP?
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft

replies.bodyText: It may be possible, but no one has asked for this yet. The customer I'm writing this for just wants AMQPS_WS to support tunneling through HTTP proxies
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Why are we adding support to deprecated API?
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -36,7 +36,7 @@

+    public @Deprecated FeedbackReceiver(String hostName, String userName, String sasToken, IotHubServiceClientProtocol iotHubServiceClientProtocol, String deviceId, ProxyOptions proxyOptions)

replies.bodyText: Good question, give me a sec to check
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I can roll back this change actually. I'll just need to throw an unsupportedOperationException if the user tries to make proxy support work with these deprecated APIs
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Breaking change?
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Good catch, here and on the other sub-service client classes. I'll add an overload constructor that takes the proxy options instead
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Isn't this a breaking change?
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft

replies.bodyText: As per above, I'll add an overload to take the proxy instead
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: If you have to pass null as an additional parameter, is that a breaking change?
timeline.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText: Looks like it, yeah. I've added an overloaded constructor so that it won't break now
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Why not group this under connection options which has protocol, proxyOptions etc and lets you add future connection options without adding extra API's
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft

     public static ServiceClient createFromConnectionString(String connectionString, IotHubServiceClientProtocol iotHubServiceClientProtocol) throws IOException

replies.bodyText: That depends on how long we plan on supporting this particular SDK. I didn't envision bringing any other options here since we will be track 2 soon. But what do you think?
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I don't forsee either (As it is hard to see for 10 years down the line). I would still prefer to group because we have to support this for 10 years even after we move to track-2 ;just to be on safer side.
replies.author: prmathur-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Do you picture a class "ConnectionOptions" being reused from AMQP to HTTP, though? Or do you picture an HttpConnectionOptions class for registry manager, and an AmqpConnectionOptions class for service client, where each class has just the proxy to set?
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I pushed a commit that shows one way to have a more general "RegistryManagerOptions" and "ServiceClientOptions" class structure. Can you take a look?
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.message:
feat(iot-service): Add proxy support for service client

refactor the way the registry manager consumes the proxy option as well, in case we need to add authentication support later as well. The proxyOptions object will allow us to add username and password if necessary

feat(iot-service): Add proxy support for service client

refactor the way the registry manager consumes the proxy option as well, in case we need to add authentication support later as well. The proxyOptions object will allow us to add username and password if necessary
RegistryManagerOptions and ServiceClientOptions instead of ProxyOptions at top level

timeline.bodyText: Q - this is for proxy support over Amqp_ws, then why don't we use socks proxy? Is that a proton-j requirement?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: The customer who prompted all this only needs support for HTTP proxies. I don't know offhand if amqps or amqps_ws work with socks proxies, or if proton-j has support for them
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I see, what does our device client currently use?
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: HTTP proxies work for device clients using MQTT_WS, AMQPS_WS, and HTTP. In theory, SOCKs proxies work for device clients using MQTT
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText:
there is a whole lot happening here, can we move this to the line above:
this.options != null && this.options.getProxyOptions() != null ? this.options.getProxyOptions().getProxy() : null
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: The way I see, registry manager options should never be null, but have some default initial value (proxy = null)
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Yeah, good call. This is pretty busy
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Why not add @AllArgsConstructor for 1 line initialization.
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+package com.microsoft.azure.sdk.iot.service;
+
+import lombok.Getter;
+import lombok.Setter;
+
+/**
+ * Configurable options for all registry manager operations
+ */
+public class RegistryManagerOptions
+{
+    /**
+     * The options that specify what proxy to tunnel through. If null, no proxy will be used
+     */
+    @Getter
+    @Setter
+    private ProxyOptions proxyOptions;

replies.bodyText: I don't want this to be construed as an essential option. As such, there should be a constructor that doesn't take this
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: For instance, if we ever add something like HTTP readTimeout/connectTimeout, I wouldn't want customers to need a proxy here
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: yeah, good point.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: But I still feel the options object in itself should not be null, but have a default value
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: That way, it signifies that it is a container for client configurations, and if we add a param that has a default non-null value, we don't have to remove the null checks from everywhere.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure I see the value in holding a non-null default proxyOptions class. Each of those null checks would just turn into checks on if the proxy is of type DIRECT (no proxy) or type HTTP.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: For AMQP in particular, it isn't just a straight pass through. We have to add a transport layer manually if there is a proxy to go through
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: What about a builder pattern here instead? Since all of the hypothetical fields in this class are optional, and we don't know how many options there may be in the future, a builder could fit in well here
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText:
Suppose tomorrow we add a parameter for Http connect timeout, which has a default value of 1min, but settable. So now, the RegistryManagerOptions class is always non-null (irrespective of proxy).
So something like this, which we have below:
options != null ? options.getProxyOptions() : null
would want to get proxy options, even though we did not set it/ want to use it.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Yeah, a builder would work here. We can set @nonnull for required params
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Okay, I pushed a commit that makes these two options classes builder based
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: I can make the RegistryManagerOptions and ServiceClientOptions always non-null, for simplicity, sure. The default proxyOptions will still be null, though
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Yes, of course, we don't want to force/ have a default for proxy
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: same, here as well
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.message: clientOptions objects are now never null

timeline.bodyText: this now needs to be options.getProxyOptions() != null
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Good catch, you are right
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.message: This once hidden constructor needs to set options to the default value, too

timeline.bodyText: what is this for? did we allow creation of registry manager without having to pass in even a connection string?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Java has a funny quirk where a class with no public constuctor automatically has a public constructor. This commit just makes that constuctor visible. I believe it was an accident that we didn't make the only constuctor protected
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Ah, the default constructor, yeah. Can we not make it private now? Also, can we modify the comment to say that this is simply the default java constructor. The replaced text makes it seem that we did allow a no args initialization of registry manager.
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: Since it was a public constructor, we can't just make it private now. That would be a breaking change. We did technically allow users to build a registry manager through that constructor. I'll add to the header here that it was once the default constructor, though
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: Oh, I am confused, if this worked, why are we deprecating this now? It is because it doesn't really do anything useful?
replies.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: nit: no longer required: ctrl+shift+o :)
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.bodyText: same, no longer required
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

timeline.message: fix constructors taking options directly not checking for null options

timeline.bodyText: Does service client works on anything other than AMQP ? If I re-call it doesn't. Then what purpose does iotHubServiceClientProtocol serve?
timeline.author: prmathur-microsoft

replies.bodyText: It can be either AMQPS or AMQPS_WS
replies.author: timtay-microsoft
